Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: Instability of Large-Scale Current Sheets, Plasmoid Formation, and Particle Acceleration in Coronal Plasmas
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigator (PI) will study magnetic reconnection as a fundamental and ubiquitous process in solar coronal plasmas. Fast magnetic reconnection is widely believed to play an important role in triggering eruptive solar flares and accelerating solar energetic particles (SEPs). Using resistive magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) and electromagnetic particle simulations, this project will investigate the connection between the so-called 'super-Alfv√©nic instability' (also known as the 'plasmoid instability') of extended current sheets and the onset and dynamics of eruptive flares.

This effort will include studies of the saturation mechanisms for the plasmoid instability, the role of the instability in loss-of-equilibrium models, and the effect of self-consistently generated plasma turbulence. The PI will also study the relative importance of collisional and collisionless reconnection regimes, as well as the transition between them, in controlling the rapid onset of eruptive flares. He will then use fully kinetic electromagnetic particle simulations to investigate the role of magnetic reconnection and multiple plasmoid formation in accelerating particles to high energies. Finally, the PI will compare the predictions of his theory and modeling efforts with observations made by spacecraft.

This project will utilize state-of-the-art high performance computing tools and develop interdisciplinary applications for the study of laboratory and space plasmas. The effort will integrate teaching and research in a university environment, involving postdoctoral research scientists and a graduate student pursuing a Ph.D. thesis. The PI will also help educate high school students in a summer institute at the University of New Hampshire known as 'Project SMART' (Science and Mathematics Achievement through Research Training). Project SMART provides exciting research experiences for local high school students in New Hampshire.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Magnetic reconnection is a fundamental and ubiquitous process in solar coronal plasmas. There is strong observational evidence that reconnection mediated by the formation of large-scale or extended current sheets play an important role in eruptive flares. The present grant was stimulated by some recent, surprising, and potentially consequential theoretical discoveries on the super-Alfvénic instability (referred to as the plasmoid instability) of large-scale current sheets and plasmoid formation. In addition to bringing in new perspectives on the problem of onset of fast reconnection that is widely believed to play an important role in triggering eruptive events, these discoveries may also contribute significantly towards a solution of the problem of particle acceleration, observed during eruptive events. By means of analysis, resistive MHD, and fully electromagnetic particle simulations, we have carried out a comprehensive research program that has : (i) established the connection between the plasmoid instability of extended current sheets and the onset and dynamics of eruptive dynamics, including studies of scaling, saturation mechanisms for the instability, the role of the instability in loss-of-equilibrium models, and the effect of self-consistently generated turbulence, (ii) determined the relative importance of collisional and collisionless reconnection regimes and the transition between them in controlling the rapid onset of eruptions, (iii) investigated the role of magnetic reconnection and multiple plasmoid formation in accelerating particles to high energies using fully kinetic electromagnetic particle simulations, and (iv) compared the predictions of theory and modeling with observations from satellite observations. 

Intellectual merit of the proposed activity

These studies involve the understanding and application of a new super-Alfvénic instability (referred to as the plasmoid instability) of large-scale current sheets to outstanding questions in solar coronal physics pertaining to flares and particle acceleration. It has also led to a new theory of supra-arcade downflows in the solar corona, a long-standing mystery associated with eruptive events.  The project involves the use of state-of-the-art high-performance computing tools and has significant interdisciplinary implications for laboratory and space plasmas.

 Broader impacts of the proposed activity

The present project integrates teaching and research at all levels in a research university, from postdoctoral research scientists to a graduate student pursuing a Ph. D. thesis. Because of the fundamental nature of the science involved in this research project, it is expected to promote interdisciplinary interactions with laboratory and a broad community of space plasma physicists.
